title: Venture capital vs crowdfunding: Whatâ€™s the right call for your business?
body: BlogVenture capital vs crowdfunding: Whatâ€™s the right call for your business?5 August 2022â€¢5-minutesStart-upsBusiness tipsIn this articleâ€¢What is venture capital, and what is its background?Â â€¢How do venture capitalists work?â€¢Pros and cons of venture capitalâ€¢What is equity crowdfunding?â€¢How does crowdfunding work?â€¢Pros and cons of equity crowdfunding (ECF)â€¢Examples of crowdfundingâ€¢Venture capital vs crowdfundingâ€¢Contact Airwallex to streamline your financesMost start-ups think that venture capital (VC) is the best source of funding available to them. But it may not always be right for your type of business. Crowdfunding is also a viable option.Â Whether youâ€™re scaling up to access more resources or you want a buffer for future growth endeavours, there are several reasons your start-up may need to secure more funding.Â Here, weâ€™ll take a look at the two most common methods of raising financing: VC and equity crowdfunding (ECF). VC is a traditional source of funding that provides you with large sums of capital from a few sources. But ECF has grown in popularity and provides modest amounts of funding more often than youâ€™d receive through VC.Â Depending on your start-up and its financial needs, one may work better than the other. Letâ€™s dig into why.Â What is venture capital, and what is its background?Â First, letâ€™s discuss the history of VC.A little backgroundVC is a subset of private equity (PE). The roots of PE go back to World War II.Â Georges Goriot, a Harvard Business School professor, is considered the father of venture capital. He founded the American Research and Development Corporation (ARD) in 1946 and raised over USD3.5 million in funding to invest in companies that created commercially saleable technology during the war.Â Goriotâ€™s first investment was USD200,000, which he put towards an X-ray technology company that treated cancer. Once the X-ray business went public in 1955, his original investment ended up growing over USD1.8 million.Â What is venture capital?VC is a subset of PE. Itâ€™s a type of financing that investors provide to start-ups and small-to medium-sized businesses (SMBs) that have the potential for long-term growth. Providing VC to businesses considering expansion is also relatively common.Â VC typically comes from investment banks and other financial institutions that scout small, young businesses (i.e. start-ups) with potential that need financial help.Â VC funding doesnâ€™t always take a monetary form. Your start-up can also receive â€˜helpâ€™ in a technical or managerial sense. But the bottom line is that providing VC is typically set aside for start-ups and small companies that have highly recognisable growth potential.Â Investors also provide VC to companies on the verge of expanding. Such companies will likely start bringing in a substantial amount of capital that will eventually pay back investors.Although itâ€™s always a risk for investors to fund small businesses (or unknown start-ups), it supports their next endeavour â€” whether thatâ€™s growth or expansion. And those endeavours will likely lead to better profitability.Â So, businesses without access to bank loans, capital markets or other monetary sources to fund their operations will typically seek out means through investors. The main downside to VC is that investors usually get equity.Â In other words, they own a portion of your company and therefore have a say in the business decisions you make. Weâ€™ll explore that a little more later.Â How do venture capitalists work?VC firms establish independent limited partnerships with businesses. In an average deal, businesses seeking funding will distribute or â€˜sellâ€™ large portions of the business to a few investors through independent limited partnerships.Â Sometimes these partnerships include similar enterprises. In this case, a venture capitalist or VC firm might invest in a particular idea that these small businesses pursue.Â However, the greatest difference between VC and other private equity deals is that VC focuses on new businesses that need first-time funding. PE typically focuses on more established, larger companies. PE deals might seek an equity infusion or even a chance for a start-upâ€™s founders to transfer their ownership.Â What is the venture capital process?The first step for any business seeking VC is to create a business plan and submit it to a VC firm or an angel investor. However, the difference between an angel investor and a venture capitalist is that an angel investor is generally an affluent person who invests their own money.A venture capitalist is usually employed at a firm that invests with risk capital. This means it invests other peopleâ€™s money rather than its own.Â If the investor is interested in the proposal, then theyâ€™ll typically thoroughly research the company. This means investigating the start-upâ€™s business model, products and services, management, operating history and more to determine whether itâ€™s worth investing a great deal of money into.Â Many investors, both venture capitalists who work at firms and angel investors who work independently, have background experience as equity research analysts. They do so most often through a particular industry, such as healthcare.Â So their research into your start-up doesnâ€™t involve deciding whether they think your business has a â€˜good ideaâ€™. They look into whether your company will realistically see growth, profitability and expansion.Â In other words, if you do well, then the investor does well. So, they look for start-ups with a high potential of performing well in a particular industry.Â Once diligent research is complete, the firm or investor proposes a pledge. This pledge is a certain amount of capital theyâ€™re willing to invest in exchange for a portion of your company (i.e. equity).Â They provide the funds either as one large, individual sum or in rounds. Distributing capital through funding rounds is most common. Once the investor or firm begins distributing funding, they take an active role in advising the company.Â By advising and monitoring the progress of the start-up, firms can steer their â€˜investmentâ€™ in the right direction for a better chance at growth. The firm might also want to see progress and success markers before releasing any additional funds.Â Once the start-up has performed well over a period, the investor or firm then exits the company. Theyâ€™ll initiate a merger, acquisition or initial public offering (IPO).Â Pros and cons of venture capitalLetâ€™s look at the pros and cons of VC to determine whether itâ€™s a suitable route for your business.Â Venture capital prosYour start-up will access a large sum of capital in a short period.Â VC firms have substantial experience investing in start-ups, so your business has a better chance of growing.Â Your start-up gains prestige and credibility if a notable firm decides to invest in it.Â Venture capital consA very small amount of start-ups receive VC, so if you do, youâ€™re part of an exclusive club â€” but itâ€™s certainly difficult to get there.Â Your investor or investor firm will pressure your start-up to perform well. This might be the push your start-up needs to see growth, but it puts stress on your business model, founders and employees.Â You lose control over your business. You wonâ€™t lose all control, but venture capitalists seek out terms that are most advantageous to them, often at the foundersâ€™ expense. They often force out company founders if the terms arenâ€™t ideal for a long enough time.[Related: Net working capital: How to calculate it and why itâ€™s important]What is equity crowdfunding?ECF involves receiving numerous small amounts of money from many people to fund your start-up.Â How many people you can access depends on the extent of your network. If your network is big, you can easily access many people. But even if your network is on the smaller side, many crowdfunding websites and social media platforms bridge the gap between entrepreneurs and investors.Â So through crowdfunding, smaller-scale start-ups can expand their pool of investors beyond relatives, founders, owners and venture capitalists.Â How does crowdfunding work?Most jurisdictions have restrictions on who can fund start-ups, as well as how much theyâ€™re allowed to contribute. These restrictions are similar to those of hedge fund investing.Â Putting regulations in place protects non-wealthy and generally naive investors from putting too much of their money into a start-up that may or may not do well. If an unsophisticated investor puts all their life savings into a start-up that ends up failing, itâ€™s detrimental to that personâ€™s future and financial stability.Â Many businesses fail, so itâ€™s reasonable to have restrictions in place.Â However, this doesnâ€™t mean that itâ€™s difficult to raise money from crowdfunding. Itâ€™s still a viable way for entrepreneurs to find the capital they need to grow. Your start-up has the potential to raise hundreds to millions of dollars. Crowdfunding is a great opportunity, as long as you have a great business idea and a convincing pitch for waiting investors.Â However, crowdfunding sites receive a portion of the funds you raise.Â [Related: How to calculate opportunity cost]Types of crowdfundingThere are two traditional types of crowdfunding. Start-ups seeking help via capital funding to bring their product or service to life is one type. People who are dealing with some sort of emergency, such as a natural disaster, medical expense or tragedy (e.g. house fire), do the other.Â However, creatives â€” including writers, artists, musicians and podcasters â€” also use crowdfunding platforms to help sustain their professional and personal lives. These creative lines of work often don't have steady or stable sources of income. So, crowdfunding is a feasible solution for those needing or offering financial help.Pros and cons of equity crowdfunding (ECF)Letâ€™s look at some of the pros and cons of ECF.Â Pros of crowdfundingStart-ups will typically offer common shares (i.e. non-voting) that allow founders to maintain control over their business rather than let investors dictate how founders carry out operations.Crowdfunding also helps start-ups gain hundreds to thousands of investors who likely later become customers. Many of them also become champions of the brand, which in turn, increases word of mouth.Â Crowdfunding also allows start-ups to constantly raise money rather than receive it as one large individual sum or in small gradual sums from investors.Â Cons of crowdfundingStart-ups donâ€™t have any certainty regarding whether theyâ€™ll meet their funding goal. When working with a VC firm, theyâ€™ll provide the amount of money that you propose you need. However, crowdfunding might not fully add up to what you need.Â All money given to start-ups through crowdfunding is public, so your financial reporting will be very transparent. It should always be transparent, but crowdfunding guarantees everyone involved knows when, from whom and how much you receive.Â Your crowdfunding campaign typically has marketing costs through the platform you use. Youâ€™ll likely also have to pay legal and accounting costs.Examples of crowdfundingHere are some popular examples of crowdfunding sites:Kickstarter: A platform that helps in bringing creative projects to life including film, music, theatre, art, photography, design and more.Â GoFundMe: An American for-profit platform that helps raise money for life events including funerals, illnesses, accidents, graduations, schooling and more.IndieGoGo: A platform that helps in raising funds for innovative ideas, charities and start-up businesses.Patreon: A membership platform providing content creators with business tools to run a subscription service to earn a monthly income. In return, subscribers earn perks.Substack: A platform providing payment, analytics, publishing and design help to support e-newsletters received by subscribers. Writers can send e-newsletters directly to subscribers.Â Oculus VR, for example, raised crowdfunded capital on Kickstarter in 2012. The start-up specialises in virtual reality (VR) software and hardware products, such as VR headsets for gamers. The foundersâ€™ original goal was to raise USD250,000, but they managed to secure USD2.4 million. Four years later in 2014, Facebook (now Meta) acquired Oculus for USD2.3 billion in both stock and cash.Â Another successful Kickstarter campaign was for M3D, which manufactures micro-3D printers. The founders were able to raise USD3.4 million for their product in 2017.Â And now, you can find their printers anywhere â€” from Amazon to Staples to Brookstonne and more. No other Kickstarter campaign has raised an amount that high over a 30- or 60-day period.Venture capital vs crowdfundingNow that you know the differences between VC and ECF, letâ€™s directly compare the two by examining their key distinctions.Your control over your start-upRaising capital through ECF is better for entrepreneurs because doing so gives them more control. Giving up board sets isnâ€™t ideal, which is what often happens when raising VC.Â So, if you choose to raise a large individual or a few sums of capital via VC, be ready to accept any terms that your investor proposes concerning your business model and operations. If you choose to raise money via crowdfunding, expect to receive small amounts of capital spanning many investors and to maintain full control over your business.Â Your investment networkThe value of your start-up (i.e. the product and service you sell) will increase alongside the higher number of buyers, sellers or users you have. This is the â€˜network effectâ€™.Â With ECF, any person who participates in your crowdfund will essentially increase in value because the network effect creates a positive feedback loop. Your returns will likely increase the bigger your network is.Â The network effect isnâ€™t achievable through VC because there isnâ€™t a network attracting another network.Â Your business model criteriaVC firms have particular criteria they use to determine what and whom they want to invest in. These criteria are generally much stricter than on crowdfunding sites. Crowdfunding sites allow you to raise small amounts of capital from several sources, but a venture capitalist or their firm will be highly involved in your business, both time- and money-wise.Â With crowdfunding, all you need is a story compelling enough to convince people to invest in your business. With VC, you need much more than a good story. You need adequate proof that your business has the potential to grow.Your investment dealVC has been around for decades, while crowdfunding is a fairly new phenomenon. Currently, there are many more VC investments than there are ECF campaigns. But analysts donâ€™t expect the situation to stay that way.Â In fact, analysts expect crowdfunding campaigns to grow in popularity because their use tripled in 2020.Â Your reputationÂ Start-ups that are more focused on their social impact are better off raising money through crowdfunding sites. Many investors on crowdfunding sites look for campaigns where their money can make a true difference in the world, such as with the environment or healthcare.Â VC traditionally funds businesses looking to make a profit â€” and not a small one, at that.Contact Airwallex to streamline your financesWhether your start-up has received funding through VC or ECF, you need a reliable way to manage your money.Â Airwallex offers Global Business Accounts that can help you unlock new global markets without losing money in FX fees.Open accounts in 11 currencies at the click of a button, enjoy fast global transfers, market-beating FX rates, and borderless cards.Â Â So no matter where your funding comes from, you can make sure more money remains available for your business endeavours rather than lost in translation.Â If youâ€™re ready to streamline your finances and improve your profit margins, donâ€™t hesitate to sign up today.Â Back to blogShareSubscribe for our latest updates straight to your inboxLoading...

title: A Conversation with HubSpot & Airwallex
body: BlogA Conversation with HubSpot & Airwallex2 August 2022â€¢5 minutesA conversation with Caitlin Siegrist, Senior Manager of Platform Ecosystems at HubSpot, Eric Bai, Manager of SME Partnerships at Airwallex, and Richard Yu, Product Lead of Ecosystem, Growth, and Lending at Airwallex.Tell us more about Airwallexâ€™s Ecosystem and Strategic Partnerships teamAirwallex (Richard/Eric): The Ecosystem teamâ€™s mission is to simplify customer operations and enable novel use cases for small and medium enterprises. We build integrations with supporting software, like accounting, customer relationship management and eCommerce platforms.Â Our team was formed last year to better serve our customers with a connected product that would help users manage their money confidently with tools theyâ€™re already familiar with. Our members work closely with Airwallexâ€™s Strategic Partnerships team responsible for managing relationships with some of the largest tech companies.How did the partnership with HubSpot start?Airwallex: Weâ€™re new to the HubSpot ecosystem, but weâ€™ve been a HubSpot customer for quite some time. Our partnership conversation with HubSpot began in earnest earlier this year. While weâ€™d identified HubSpot as a potential partner and had a few preliminary conversations, our Ecosystem product team had been focused on launching integrations with Netsuite, Zapier and Xero.Â It wasnâ€™t until we took part in the App Accelerator program that we started exploring a possible integration. Their team was seeking out partners as part of their international program, and we realized this was the perfect opportunity for us to look more deeply into an integration.What made the accelerator an especially useful program for Airwallex?Airwallex: A few things stood out to us as we learned more about the accelerator. Firstly, the program provided dedicated developer advocates who helped us investigate HubSpot API endpoints and possible flows for our integration. Secondly, HubSpotâ€™s Partnerships team helped us answer questions about our multi-regional customersâ€™ needs, our core market. And finally, the many co-marketing opportunities we could participate in to help increase awareness of our solution for joint customers.How did the product organization at Airwallex decide to build a direct integration with HubSpot?Airwallex: The acceleratorâ€™s required timeline was to design and build an integration in three months. This was the fastest integration built by our team, and it took careful planning and decision-making.We considered working with third-party developers, who we also work with on other integrations. We also assessed the tradeoffs of prioritizing this integration. In order to proceed, weâ€™d likely have to delay building another integration.Â Ultimately, we decided to move forward with a direct integration based on the size of our existing mutual customer base with HubSpot and our conviction of the opportunity as HubSpotâ€™s partner. Our goal is to provide a great customer experience for HubSpotâ€™s customers.What customer problem is Airwallex trying to solve by building an integration with HubSpot?Airwallex: When youâ€™re a business owner operating across multiple regions, you might find yourself paying unnecessary fees for foreign exchange and payment processing. You might also find your banking system and CRM donâ€™t talk, making it difficult for your finance and sales teams to collect payments and track cash flow.Â Airwallex, through its integration with HubSpot, offers a single, user-friendly solution for getting paid. The integration uses Airwallexâ€™s shareable, no-code payment links which accept payments in over 170+ local currencies and settle like-for-like into your account. Customers can then use these funds to pay their vendors and expenses.Â For each deal in HubSpot, the integration creates a payment link unique to the deal and syncs payment events directly to the deal. This saves customers a great deal of time switching between Airwallex and HubSpot, empowers HubSpot Sales Hub users to request and track payments from their customers, and helps finance teams track cash flow while maintaining secure access to the companyâ€™s Airwallex account.What makes HubSpot an attractive ecosystem to develop integrations for?Airwallex: HubSpot is a huge player in the CRM space. It has a vast ecosystem of developer and solutions partners which provide real value to its customers. According to IDC, the HubSpot ecosystem is forecast to grow faster than HubSpot as its revenue grows from $4.8 billion in 2020 to $12.5 billion in 2024.Â Aside from the addressable market, HubSpotâ€™s developer platform and support is a big draw â€” theyâ€™re clearly taking a calculated bet on the success of its partners.Why did HubSpot choose to work with Airwallex for its international app accelerator?HubSpot:Â Out of several concepts submitted to the accelerator, we found Airwallexâ€™s to be one of the most exciting. Airwallexâ€™s robust payment and FX capabilities are unique for allowing customers to collect payments across multiple currencies and also settle them like-for-like without incurring double currency conversions. This is a large demand gap for companies operating globally and enables them to spend on fees and more on growth. In addition, Airwallexâ€™s large customer base had considerable overlap with HubSpotÂ which made the accelerator an ideal opportunity to partner more closely together.Why is addressing the needs of global and multi-market customers a key priority for HubSpot?HubSpot:Â While HubSpotâ€™s CRM Platform provides marketing, sales, and customer service capabilities that almost all businesses need, applications like Airwallex provide specialized functionality for companies operating globally. Businesses who operate across different countries face unique challenges including dealing with multiple languages, currencies and payment methods.Â HubSpot supports over 143,000 companies in more than 120 countries. IDC expects HubSpot customers to become increasingly international, with North American revenue going from nearly 60% of the total in 2020 to under 45% by 2024. The company also has offices all over the world, including recent expansions in Spain, Netherlands and Quebec, Canada. This is a huge area of focus for HubSpot and which is why weâ€™ve made this a key theme for our spring accelerator.What are your future plans for the partnership?Airwallex: Right now, weâ€™re focused on our existing joint customers and educating them on the benefits of the integration. In the future, expect to see more co-marketing efforts between the two companies and exploring deeper ways to partner together.Â Airwallex will also be expanding the capabilities of our payment link product, such as accepting bank transfers or direct debit. Weâ€™ll also be building additional integrations with HubSpot, including Quotes and Marketing Hub.Thanks, any further thoughts?AWX: Read more details about our app in HubSpotâ€™s app marketplace â€” and if youâ€™re not already an Airwallex customer, youâ€™ll have fees returned on your first $20,000 FX processed when you sign up for a free borderless business account via this link. HubSpot: If you have an app that could connect with HubSpot, weâ€™d love to talk to you about participating in our App Accelerator program. Back to blogShareSubscribe for our latest updates straight to your inboxLoading...

title: How to Hire for Success When Youâ€™re an Unknown Startup
body:
BlogHow to Hire for Success When Youâ€™re an Unknown Startup29 July 2022â€¢5 minutesStart-upsBusiness tipsIn this articleâ€¢What are the challenges of hiring for a start-up?â€¢How to hire employees for your unknown start-upâ€¢What to look for in employeesâ€¢When and whom should you hire?â€¢Creating a hiring process for your start-upâ€¢Contact Airwallex to support your startupâ€™s financial endeavorsAs your start-up begins to grow, youâ€™ll likely need to hire more people outside of your founding team. However, that early on, each new hire has the potential to change your businessâ€™s DNA.Â So itâ€™s better to sculpt a strategic hiring process now rather than later if you want to hire for success when youâ€™re an unknown start-up. Because after funding, the biggest hurdle youâ€™ll face is hiring.Â For start-ups, having the right people in the right roles especially matters. You canâ€™t afford to lose the time when seed funding and other nascent phases of your business are ongoing.What are the challenges of hiring for a start-up?Every stage of growth has unique challenges when hiring for a start-up. But letâ€™s explore the challenges that founders might face during a start-upâ€™s earliest stages.Â Every hire mattersAs your start-up begins to gain steam, youâ€™ll notice that every hire has an impact on your growth and culture.Â When your team is still small, new hires influence the quantity and quality of the work you put out. They also affect the teamâ€™s culture, capabilities and general morale.Â Start-ups are high riskJoining a start-up isnâ€™t the right career choice for everyone. Some people prefer more stability, larger teams and greater predictability when it comes to clients and assignments. Others enjoy the fast pace and donâ€™t care so much about the business they work for not having a long, successful track record.Â This makes finding the right people both easy and difficult. There aren't as many people on the market who enjoy the instability, but at least you know those who come in for interviews or are already hired are there because they truly want to be.Â Youâ€™re unknownAttracting talent â€” let alone finding talent â€” is difficult when youâ€™re unknown. Unless your founding members have a reputation and are generally noteworthy, your start-upâ€™s name isnâ€™t going to ring a bell for anyone.Â Youâ€™ll have to really sell your vision and impress not only your investors but also potential candidates who are considering joining your team.Â How to hire employees for your unknown start-upSo, how do you hire for success when youâ€™re an unknown start-up? The first step is attracting talent.Â You want to ensure your business attracts top-quality candidates because at the end of the day, your start-up is only as successful as the people you bring on.Â Build an appealing businessYour earliest team members will likely be people who were all more or less in the same professional network. Hiring remains flexible at this point.Â But later, youâ€™ll need to build a business that people outside of your immediate network will want to work for. And this doesnâ€™t mean a fancy office or free lunches â€” it means making your cultural work values clear.Â Business valuesYour start-upâ€™s values are synonymous with your identity as both an employer and a business overall. Itâ€™s best to define those values early so that you start on the right footing and thereâ€™s no confusion concerning what you expect from hires.Â Online presenceBecause youâ€™re likely unknown, at least for the most part, creating an online presence will help you gain an identity in the public eye. Being strategic with what you put on your website and what you post on your social media platforms is essential. And you should keep content consistent among all your outlets.Â CompensationWhile any talented person will find competitive pay one of the more attractive components of a role, not all hires will put it at the top of their list. But that doesnâ€™t mean it shouldnâ€™t be at the top of yours.Â In your early stages, most employees will likely be underpaid. Start-ups arenâ€™t rolling in profit yet! But you should plan to bring employees up to market rate as soon as youâ€™re able.Â Additionally, offering equity will appeal to more applicants. A higher salary is a plus, but itâ€™s common for early employees at a start-up to have equity included in their compensation package. Ownership through equity helps buffer the initially lower pay because itâ€™ll pay off eventually when the business does well and grows its stock.Â Finding candidatesNetworking and sourcing are equally important when reaching candidates. You should constantly recruit, even if you only have the resources to grow your team bit by bit.Â You can network by attending conferences, meetups, webinars and talks. This helps you create a real-world foundation for your next potential hire.Â Sourcing involves directly reaching out to candidates within your immediate and extended network. For example, the people on your current team are there for a reason. And they probably know other people with similar skill sets who may be interested in joining your start-up.Â Sharing next-hire requirements with your team will allow them to reach out to their contacts and essentially take the recruiting work off your hands.Â What to look for in employeesHere are some key areas to consider when identifying potential hires.Skill vs attitudeÂ Itâ€™s tempting to think that the most qualified candidate is the one who has everything youâ€™re looking for on paper: an impressive resume, cover letter, experience and credentials.Â But sometimes attitude and personality matter more for early teams because a start-upâ€™s nature is usually risky and unpredictable. But itâ€™s also exciting, and it takes a particularly motivated personality to thrive in that environment.Â Experience vs potentialItâ€™s always better to hire someone who has a lot of experience rather than someone with little to no experience. But a candidate who misses the mark by just a hair in terms of years of experience could very well have great potential.Â A candidate with great potential will be highly motivated and excited to learn. Sometimes, a potential hire with the most years of experience wonâ€™t have the drive to go beyond the credentials they have.Â In this case, use your best judgement. Finding someone with the right mix of potential and experience will work best in your favour in the long term.Cultural fitSimilar to personality or attitude, cultural fit isnâ€™t something you can decipher when skimming someoneâ€™s resume, cover letter, licences and certificates. But itâ€™s crucial nonetheless.Your earliest employees are integral members of your team. They set the tone for how your start-up will operate.Â What types of people do you want to work with? What types of people will set the foundation for a healthy cultural standard in the workplace?Â Once your cultural tone is set, youâ€™ll have a healthier overall workplace â€” onethat future hires will likely feel comfortable being part of.On that note, itâ€™s advantageous and ethical to hire people who donâ€™t â€˜look like you.â€™ A lack of diversity in the workplace sets your business back. Employees who come from various walks of life, ethnicities and backgrounds will bring their own unique, personal ideas to the forefront.Â And in turn, that will help you sell products and provide services to all different types of people.When and whom should you hire?Your start-upâ€™s needs will certainly change over time. And what you look for in a candidate will change as well. The hire who works well for your business right now may not work well later.Â Additionally, your start-upâ€™s type and workload demands will fluctuate. Itâ€™s beneficial to.use these factors as references for hires.Â Whom to hireOnce your start-up begins to grow, your priorities will change. This could mean changes in your product and service offerings or even developmental changes.Â As a result, the roles you need to fill will change. You might need more people in your software engineering department if you want to focus more of your money and effort on developing a certain product or platform.Â Or maybe your product is up to par. In that case, you might want to start bringing people into your human resources department because youâ€™re behind in administrative work.Â When to hireAn important aspect of hiring for your start-up is being selective with timing. If you hire too many people very early, you might be stretched for cash. Or maybe you hire more people than you need, and employees have too much free time.Â Ultimately, this wastes time and money.Here are a few questions to consider before hiring:Do you have the funds to support a new hire (e.g. training, salary)?Is there enough work to occupy a new hire?Do you have the time to scout and recruit talented prospects?
Youâ€™ll typically instinctively know when itâ€™s time to hire because work will pile up. Or maybe your finances are doing well, and youâ€™re no longer struggling with the means to pay your team.Â If your existing team begins to feel strained, then itâ€™s probably time for you to expand the team.Â Creating a hiring process for your start-upHereâ€™s a rough outline of how to write a job description for your start-up:Â A section about your businessA job description summaryÂ Perk and compensation detailsOnce youâ€™ve written your job description and candidates start reaching out, you need to do a few things from the point of application to hire.Â Screen applications: Compare applications to determine who has the required skills based on the job description. Additionally, you can spot any red flags.Â Give a practical skills test: The skills you test will vary depending on the role. You can distribute a test before, during or after an interview.Â Interview candidates: Many businesses now have hybrid work environments, so you can conduct interviews either in person or virtually. Interviews are less about quizzing a candidate and more about determining whether they have values and personality traits that mesh with your businessâ€™s workplace culture.Â Pick a candidate: Many businesses will put candidates in a spreadsheet and score them based on cultural fit, skills fit and practical fit (e.g. salary, commute). And as youâ€™d expect, whoever ranks highest is likely the best pick for the job. However, itâ€™s wise to pick a candidate who ranks equally among all aspects â€” not super high on one and low on others.Â Contact Airwallex to support your startupâ€™s financial endeavorsBuilding a great team is the biggest indicator of success for your start-up. So once your start-up gains some stable footing, sign up for a free Global Business Account with Airwallex.Â Weâ€™ll help you streamline your finances and improve your profit margins so that your success doesnâ€™t stall. Better money management will help your business stay organised and will help you tackle future opportunities to increase your ROI.Related article: How to calculate ROIBack to blogShareSubscribe for our latest updates straight to your inboxLoading...

title: Net working capital: How to calculate it and why itâ€™s important
body:
BlogNet working capital: How to calculate it and why itâ€™s important29 July 2022â€¢5 minutesBusiness tipsStart-upsIn this articleâ€¢What is working capital?â€¢Why does working capital matter?â€¢How to calculate working capitalâ€¢Advantages of working capitalÂ â€¢Limitations of working capitalÂ â€¢Example of working capitalâ€¢What does negative working capital mean for your business?â€¢How to improve your working capitalâ€¢Expand your business whilst reducing costs with AirwallexKeeping your business running and thriving requires planning. This is why entrepreneurs and business owners work to better understand the ins and outs of net working capital.Â What does it mean? How much do I need? Is it even that important?Once you understand what net working capital is, you can answer all those questions and stabilise your businessâ€™s finances. And stability will help your operations not only run smoother but also last for the long term. Closing a business because you made mistakes that you could have easily prevented is never fun.Â But first things first â€” net working capital and working capital are synonymous. Both represent the difference between your current liabilities and your current assets. However, some financial analysts define net working capital a little more narrowly than others.Â Letâ€™s explore the matter.What is working capital?Working capital is what keeps a business up and running while it has expenditures.Â Most businesses have customers who owe them a little (or a lot of) money. But you canâ€™t always rely on customers to immediately pay you what youâ€™re owed. Nevertheless, the lights need to stay on somehow.Â Thatâ€™s what working capital is. Itâ€™s the capital your business runs on while youâ€™re both earning and spending money.Â With working capital, you have the option to restock your inventory after selling goods. This is true even if customers purchase by signing up for payment instalments, so you donâ€™t get everything youâ€™re owed immediately. Your working capital allows you to keep your business operating regardless.Net working capital is quite similar to (if not the same as) working capital, but it has a slightly narrower definition. Net working capital represents the assets you have, not just your on-hand cash. Here are a few examples:Balance in your bank accountAmount of on-hand cashÂ Merchandise inventoryAny financial investmentsYour accounts receivableBoth net working capital and working capital represent your businessâ€™s ability to continue operating while also paying its debts.Â Why does working capital matter?The main goal of any small- to medium-sized business (SMB) or large enterprise is to return money to its investors. When you think about it, it makes sense that investors pay attention to business owners who do more than just keep the lights and water on.Â Investors look at businesses that have a strong chance of growing and thus earning more in the future. That earned money will eventually flow back to the investor to replace what they funded.Â Working capital keeps a business up and running, but any entrepreneur understands that the net working capital amount determines a businessâ€™s debt capacity. Or in other words, how much is this business really worth? And if it needs to handle debt down the road, what can it liquidate to pay it off?Net working capital and working capital also determine the direction an investment should go and whether suppliers can influence negotiations.Â How to calculate working capitalNow that you know what working capital is and why it matters, letâ€™s look into how to calculate it.First, you have to identify your current assets and liabilities. But what exactly are they?Current assetsIn accounting terms, a current asset is a businessâ€™s cash, as well as all the goods it has that it can convert into cash within a short period (12 months). This also includes incoming earnings.When you look at a businessâ€™s balance sheet, youâ€™ll find its liquidity, with each asset having a unique liquidation amount.Here are examples of current assets:Cash. This includes the money in your bank account as well as checks or other forms of customer payment that you havenâ€™t deposited yet.Accounts receivable. Your total accounts receivables is the money youâ€™re currently owed and receiving through accounts minus the allowances that likely wonâ€™t be paid.Notes receivable. This could be short-term loans (ones that expire within one year) to suppliers or customers.Other receivables. These include any cash advances you give to employees, insurance claims and income tax refunds.Â Short-term investments. These usually entail investments that a business intends to sell within 12 months.Marketable securities. This includes money market funds or US Treasury bills.Inventory. This indicates raw materials (e.g. textiles), works in progress and finished goods.Prepaid expenses and advance payments. This could mean prepaid insurance premiums or purchases youâ€™ve set in place for the future.
As for liabilities, which are on a separate part of a balance sheet, youâ€™ll see short-term debts (again, within a 12-month period). These liabilities usually refer to payments you owe suppliers, your taxes, any financial charges and more.Â Here are examples of current liabilities:Accounts payableNotes payable (within 12 months)Taxes payableWages payableLoan interest payableLoan principal owed within one yearVariable accrued expensesAdvance customer payments for any goods or services that have yet to be delivered (e.g. deferred revenue)
Hereâ€™s the working capital formula:Current assets âˆ’ Current liabilities = Working capital.If your result is in the negative, this means your business will likely need to pursue third-party capital (such as a bank loan) to pay any outstanding debts.Â Advantages of working capitalÂ Next, weâ€™ll examine some advantages of working capital.Ensures liquidityBusinesses often experience financial hardship when they have an ineffective working capital management policy.Â Working capital management monitors accounts payable and receivable, stocks, debt and more to ensure liquidity in the business. If the business needs cash for any short-term debts or operations, itâ€™s available at any time.Avoids operational interruptionWorking capital allows you to keep your operations moving without any stops. Better yet, detailed information about your working capital (e.g. how much you have) allows you to make sound business decisions concerning where to put your time and money.Â Ultimately, this knowledge gives you an advantage over your competitors.Â Increases profitProperly applying your working capital allows you to increase your profit in the long run. This is because you can better manage your inventory and thus avoid failure in your operations.Â Collecting and paying trade receivables on time are key aspects of managing your working capital, too. Thatâ€™s because youâ€™re properly allocating cash and managing what comes in before it goes out.Â Improves financial stabilityBecause working capital is essentially an assessment of money going in and out, you can better allocate your businessâ€™s cash.Â Working capital also allows business owners to avoid legal troubles that may arise if they lack enough of it. When you have more than enough working capital, you can unlock opportunities that may otherwise be unavailable.Â Limitations of working capitalÂ Here, weâ€™ll delve into some limitations of working capital.Only monetaryÂ Working capital includes only items of monetary value, such as finished goods, debts receivables and more. When determining your working capital, you donâ€™t consider nonmonetary items such as the impact of recessions and governmental policies affecting your particular industry.Â Non-situationalWorking capital is naturally non-situational. It takes time to respond to any changes in the market, and working capital doesnâ€™t acknowledge the impact it takes on profit due to slower business operations.Data-basedÂ Working capital relies on data, so your strategy holds no relevance without concrete numbers. One example is with trade receivables. You need your date of sale, number of days in a grace period, penalty amount for unfulfilled payments and more.Â Example of working capitalLetâ€™s say your total current assets equal $740,000. This includes cash, finished inventory, raw materials and accounts receivable.Â However, your current liabilities equal $405,000. This might be for employee wages, business taxes, office rent, utilities, subscriptions and any debts due within the year.Â Your working capital would then total $335,000. Following the formula above, your current assets amount ($740,000) minus your current liabilities amount ($405,000) equals your working capital ($335,000).What does negative working capital mean for your business?Several risks accompany lack of control over your working capital. Your cash can become negative, which threatens the efficiency and stability of your overall operations.Â Itâ€™s vital that you prevent a deficit in your current assets to ensure your balance remains positive.Â Here are some tips to help you maintain a positive current asset value:Â Know your businessâ€™s financial cycle and cash flow (whatâ€™s coming in and whatâ€™s going out).Document all your business processes so that you have content and data to reference if things go wrong.Control defaulters.Instate a policy that controls the reduction of your expenses and costs.
Negative working capital could result in laying off workers, paying suppliers late or shutting down warehouses or stores. Thatâ€™s why you want to ensure your current assets remain positive, and doing so requires favourable business conditions.This will help you meet customersâ€™ needs, maintain trusted relationships with suppliers and vendors, and keep up with market growth.How to improve your working capitalIf your working capital starts to decrease from a lack of sales, or if you want to increase it for project-related reasons, itâ€™s time to think of ways to improve it.You can improve your working capital in one or two ways:Reducing your current liabilitiesIncreasing your current assetsOne way to increase your current assets is by taking on long-term debt. The word â€œdebtâ€ might seem frightening, but long-term debt will actually increase your current assets by adding to your businessâ€™s available cash and not drastically increasing your current liabilities.Â To reduce your current liabilities, you can also refinance your short-term debt to long-term debt. Because your debt is no longer due within a 12-month period, your current liabilities will decrease.Another way to increase your current assets is to sell non-liquid assets for cash. And as stated earlier, when you have more cash, you have more working capital.We recommend managing your inventory well to reduce potential overstocking as well as to decrease the likelihood of your business writing off items. This relates to reducing your overall expenses, which in turn reduces your current liabilities.Â Additionally, we suggest automating your payment monitoring and accounts receivable. As a result, your cash flow will increase, and you wonâ€™t have to dig into your working capital as often to cover your day-to-day operations.Â Expand your business whilst reducing costs with AirwallexIf youâ€™re looking for a reliable, cost-effective and efficient way to streamline your finances and improve your profit margins, sign up for a free Global Business Account with Airwallex.Â Our multi-currency account aligns with more than 11 currencies, which makes it easier than ever to manage your money domestically and internationally. And if your business ends up growing with the potential to expand, our platform will support you along the way. Related article: How to calculate cost of sales for your businessBack to blogShareSubscribe for our latest updates straight to your inboxLoading...

title: Choosing your North Star Metric
body: BlogChoosing your North Star Metric29 July 2022â€¢5 minutesStart-upsBusiness tipsIn this articleâ€¢What is a North Star metric?â€¢North Star metric examplesâ€¢Why choosing a North Star metric is importantâ€¢North Star metric frameworkâ€¢How to define your North Star metricâ€¢North Star metric vs. OKRâ€¢When to adapt your North Star metricâ€¢Contact AirwallexEvery business owner wants to know if their operations are headed in the right direction. But sometimes itâ€™s difficult to pinpoint which areas are thriving and which need improvement.Â Choosing your North Star Metric is a great place to start.Â Itâ€™ll help you better measure your progress, reflect on your customer value and ultimately boost your revenue.Â What is a North Star metric?A North Star metric is a measurement that accurately predicts a businessâ€™s success â€” specifically its long-term potential. One of the key aspects of North Star metrics is that they may vary among businesses.Â What one business deems its North Star metric might differ significantly from that of another. However, your business isnâ€™t excluded to only one metric.Â Most large businesses have one to three North Star metrics, but smaller operations are fine with just one. It all depends on the businessâ€™s type, size and goals.Â A good North Star metric will accomplish these actions:Lead to revenueReflect customer valueMeasure progressAdditionally, business owners rely on a North Star metric to determine goals and other more specific metrics for individual product teams. The metric helps you define the relationship between your customers and your products. And once you define that relationship, you can point out any gaps or weak areas for your product team to improve and thus better satisfy customers and earn more revenue.North Star metric examplesAs stated above, a North Star metric varies depending on a businessâ€™s size, type and goals. But the key aspect is that it isnâ€™t the same for every business. It can be, but every business and its teams have their own sets of goals to reach, even if theyâ€™re competitors.Â One example is a tech North Star metric â€” Facebook. The social media platformâ€™s North Star metric is the number of monthly active users. By contrast, Airbnbâ€™s metric is the number of nights booked.Â Depending on your area of business, letâ€™s say sales engagement, your North Star metric could be the number of new subscribers or the number of new accounts opened.Â Or letâ€™s say a business like Instacar wants to focus its North Star metric on new user activation. The number of weekly users completing a first order could very well be its ideal North Star metric to indicate future revenue.Â Or, an eCommerce North Star metric might be the number of mobile orders delivered. An eCommerce business might have a current strategy focused on increasing orders through its mobile app, with customers having a satisfactory buying experience. This could mean no returns, easy payment methods and generally no complaints.Â A business-to-business (B2B) north star metric or a software as a service (SaaS) North Star metric might rely on HubSpot or Dropbox. This North Star metric could be four active users in week two after starting a trial account. This metric allows the B2B company to determine whether free trial accounts are useful, or in other words, whether the strategy turns leads into customers.Â Â Why choosing a North Star metric is importantChoosing a North Star metric is important because it helps you better understand your businessâ€™s overall position. Consider it a sort of birdâ€™s-eye view.Â When you can visualize where things currently are, then you can determine whatâ€™s doing well, whatâ€™s not doing so well and what could use a nudge in a different direction. This not only sets you on a smarter path to success but also improves employee retention.Â Your team will have a better understanding of the business at large as well as where itâ€™s going. What employee wouldnâ€™t want to be at a business thatâ€™s growing successfully on the up and up rather than at a standstill? Reduced turnover keeps your business on stable ground so you arenâ€™t constantly training new members.Â North Star metric frameworkAny North Star metric should consist of two parts:A statement explaining your product or business visionA metric representing the key measure for achieving your visionÂ Once you have a vision, you can determine the metric(s) you want to focus on. Most businesses focus on one of three:Transaction â€” the number of commercial transactions users or customers make on your platformProductivity â€” the number of valued digital tasks customers can perform on your platform or productÂ Attention â€” the amount of time you can engage customers with your product or on your platformSo, you have your vision and metric and now you can start strategizing.Â How to define your North Star metricNow that you know what a North Star metric is, letâ€™s explore how to define yours. The most important aspect to consider when determining your North Star metric is the game you want to play, or in other words, the area(s) you want to focus on.Â There are generally six categories of North Star metrics. This list represents the most to least common ones:Â Revenue â€” the amount of money youâ€™re bringing inCustomer growth â€” the number of customers your business hasÂ Consumption growth â€” how often customers use your productEngagement growth â€” the number of active customers you haveGrowth efficiency â€” the efficiency of how much money you earn vs. spendUser experience â€” how engaging or easy your product is to customersMost businesses focus on revenue because increased profit is the most noticeable indicator of growth. But examining your revenue balance sheets will ultimately help you determine whether you're meeting your desired profit numbers.Taking a look at the back end of your business will also give you clarity on where thereâ€™s room for improvement. This could mean data showing your number of product users or how long they stay on your site.North Star metric vs. OKRSo, you might be wondering what the difference is between a North Star metric and objective and key results (OKR).Â Well, OKR is a method that synchronizes a businessâ€™s goals on an individual level to a global scale. OKR helps businesses determine and set goals on a quarterly basis.Â An OKR file has four categories:Global â€” These are large-scale business goals decided on a quarterly basis.Â Units â€” A businessâ€™s departmental leaders will decide which goals theyâ€™ll take on and decide which teams will help them achieve those goals.Â Teams â€” Teams will determine the direction they want to take and which projects will help them reach a goal.Â Persons â€” Each team member will determine which project they can undertake to help achieve the overall goals.Â A North Star metric helps your business stay aligned with its OKR. Without a clear vision determined by OKR, itâ€™s infeasible to decide your North Star metric. In other words, a North Star metric and OKR arenâ€™t synonymous, but they work with each other to help goals remain clear and to know what to measure when working towards those goals.Â When to adapt your North Star metricBefore adapting a North Star metric, your business must have the right culture and infrastructure in place.Â You need to ensure you have aligned expectations and punctual communication within your business before moving forward with your North Star metric. If thereâ€™s no willingness to prioritize the business (its team, goals, and success), then thereâ€™s no use in working towards your North Star metric.Â For example, if you work for a commission-based sales business, sales teams and their compensation might present a conflict of interest when working towards a collective goal.Â The bottom line is to ensure everyone on your team has clear responsibilities, is collaborative and motivated when tending to those responsibilities and has the common goal for the business to excel.Â When you think about it, if a business isnâ€™t successful, then that usually means its team isn't, either. And who doesnâ€™t want to be successful?Contact AirwallexAchieving your North Star metric allows you to effectively scale your business. But to do that, you need to have the right tools in place.Sign up for a free Global Business Account with Airwallex today to reduce your profit margins, streamline your finances and push into new markets. Youâ€™ll notice your North Star metric becoming more and more attainable.Related article: How to calculate burn rateBack to blogShareSubscribe for our latest updates straight to your inboxLoading...

body:
BlogJuly release notes 2022: Shopify integration, Borderless Cards and Payment LinksTilly Michell25 July 2022â€¢3 minutesCompany newsIn this articleâ€¢New features ğŸ‰â€¢Improvements ğŸ¨Hey, howâ€™s business? July might be holiday season for some, but weâ€™ve spent most of this month indoors working feverishly on some great new features that will help you streamline your finances and reach more customers globally.Â And we wouldnâ€™t have it any other way! Read on to find out whatâ€™s new for July.Â New features ğŸ‰Localise your Shopify checkout ğŸ›’The best way to convert international customers at checkout is to make them feel at home.Â Enter the new Airwallex Shopify integration.Â Plug Airwallex into your Shopify store and offer 30+ local payment methods that suit your customers, wherever they are. Including WeChat Pay, Alipay, Klarna and Bancontact.Our integration requires no coding or technical knowledge, simply plug in and start converting more customers globally. You can also save on fees by collecting multi-currency payments directly into your Airwallex Global Account without forced currency conversions or high FX fees.Â Get in contact with your dedicated account manager to learn more.Â Hong Kong - letâ€™s get physical ğŸ‡­ğŸ‡°Want to reward your team with their own physical Employee Cards? Of course you do.Physical Employee and Company Cards are now available in Hong Kong. Customise cards with your company branding for a stylish look that shows you mean business.Â Â Â Apple Pay in the UK ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§Â UK customers can now connect their Employee Cards to Apple Pay, for borderless spending on the move.Â Give your employees a virtual card that they can use while out and about. Set spending limits for each card, and upload and approve receipts in a click.Â Improvements ğŸ¨Expense management just got even easier ğŸ’³â€œHang on, why did we buy 400 frisbees in March?â€Sometimes corporate expenses need a bit of explanation. To make things easier, any notes added to expenses in Airwallex will now automatically sync through to Xero. So your accounting team will know exactly what each expense is for.Â Plus, you can now cut down on admin by approving multiple expenses in one go.Â Â Collect essential customer data when you get paid ğŸ“¦You can now choose which information to collect from customers when they pay you by Payment Link.Need to know where to ship a customer order? Easy. Want to collect a customerâ€™s email address and phone number? No problem.Â Simply select the fields you want to include, preview the page, and click to create a Payment Link.Â Thatâ€™s it for our July round-up. We hope these new features will help smooth your path to global success. Have something youâ€™d like to see earlier for your region on our roadmap? Let us know here.

title: 10 key business metrics every startup founder needs to know
body:
Blog10 key business metrics every startup founder needs to know  Tilly Michell18 July 2022â€¢5 minutesIn this articleâ€¢The North Star Metricâ€¢
Cash Burn RateÂ â€¢Working Capitalâ€¢Customer Acquisition Cost (CAC)â€¢
Customer lifetime valueâ€¢Payback periodsâ€¢Gross, operating and net profit marginâ€¢Net revenue retentionÂ â€¢Monthly recurring revenue (MRR)â€¢Churn rateâ€¢Improve profit margins and scale your business with AirwallexÂ As a startup founder, you need to run a tight ship.In order to secure investment, allocate budget correctly, and achieve your long-term growth ambitions, you must keep a close eye on your key business metrics.Â But which metrics? I hear you ask.Â Whilst there are several business KPIs that can be used to track the success of your marketing, product and sales initiatives, there are a handful of core business metrics that offer a birds eye view of your companyâ€™s progress towards exponential growth.Â Â Â These are the numbers that venture capitalists will look at when deciding whether to invest in your startup. They are the metrics that you should discuss in your board meetings and with your employees. They will help you pinpoint and fix the fault lines in your strategy, and ensure that your company continues in a straight line towards sustainable profit.Â If you ever find yourself stuck in an elevator with an angel investor, these are the metrics you want to know off the top of your head.Â The North Star MetricThe term â€˜North Star Metricâ€™ was first coined by startup investor Sean Ellis. In his own words, the point of the North Star Metric is: â€œto align everyone on your team to work together to grow it.â€Your North Star Metric is a way of ensuring that everyone in your company is moving towards a common goal. If a project is not contributing to the North Star Metric, thereâ€™s a high chance your employees shouldnâ€™t be working on it.Â Â Silicon Valley leaders use the North Star Metric to prioritise projects and efficiently assign resources. For example, the North Star Metric at Meta is â€˜monthly active usersâ€™. This metric sits at the top of Metaâ€™s strategy, and all their initiatives contribute in some way towards improving it.Â When choosing your North Star Metric, itâ€™s important to look at the big picture.Â Take for example a SaaS business which generates revenue through a monthly subscription model. The founders of this business might choose â€˜monthly sign upsâ€™ as their North Star Metric, and congratulate themselves on a job well done. Following this North Star Metric, the marketing team could decide to put all resources into driving sign-ups to a free trial. This isnâ€™t necessarily a bad strategy, and would certainly increase interest in the product, but problems will arise if the free trials never convert to paid subscriptions.Â Â Â Â For this reason â€˜monthly sign upsâ€™, whilst an important metric, may not be the best North Star for the business, as it only provides one half of the overall goal.Â Â The best North Star Metrics offer a clear picture of a companyâ€™s overarching objective. They should be simple to understand, easy to track, and align with your company mission.Â [Related: Choosing your North Star Metric]
Cash Burn RateÂ Cash burn rate is a measurement of how quickly your business is spending (or burning through) money. Itâ€™s a particularly critical business metric for startups, which are likely to be operating at a loss in their early years.Â Â Burn rate is used for calculating cash runwayâ€”thatâ€™s the amount of time your business has left before it runs out of money.Â Venture-backed businesses use burn rate and cash runway when planning their funding rounds. In turn, investors use burn rate as an indication of how wisely a business is spending its money.Â Running out of money is the number one reason startups fail, and no venture capitalist wants to invest in a doomed project, but that doesnâ€™t mean you should aim for the slowest cash burn rate possible. In fact, VCs are likely to view a sluggish burn rate as a red flag, as it could indicate that you arenâ€™t investing money in your businessâ€™ growth.
There are two ways to calculate cash burn rate:1. Gross burn rate: this is the amount your company is spending on operating costs each month. It does not take into account your revenue. 

The formula for gross burn rate is:Operating costs / number of months = gross burn rate
2. Net burn rate: this is the amount of money your company is losing each month. Net burn rate takes your revenue into account. So if youâ€™re spending a lot, but also making a lot of money back in revenue, your net burn rate will be mitigated. You should always use net burn rate when calculating your cash runway. 

The formula is:

(Starting balance - ending balance) / number of months = net burn rateUltimately, managing cash burn rate means finding the right balance between profitability and growth. As a founder, you need to decide whether to retain your profits, or invest them back into your business.Â [Related: How to calculate cash burn rate the right way!]
ğŸ’µ Top tip: A good way to lower your cash burn rate is to cut out needless expenses. With an Airwallex account, you can collect customer payments in multiple currencies without paying high FX or transaction fees. Meaning you can scale your business globally without the associated costs. Sign up for a free account to learn more.Â Working CapitalWorking capital, also known as net working capital or NWC, is a metric that investors use to evaluate a companyâ€™s financial health and operating efficiency.Positive working capital indicates that a company has enough available liquid assets to fund future growth. Negative working capital suggests that a company does not have enough cash to pay off its debts and continue running with the same operational costs.Â A company with negative working capital may have to sell its assets and cut its operational costs or risk bankruptcy.Â Â To calculate working capital, you subtract your current liabilities (money that will need to be paid within the next 12 months, including staff wages, accounts payable and tax) from your current assets (assets that you have or expect to receive within the next 12 months, including accounts receivable, unsold inventory and cash).Â Â The formula looks like this:Â Current assets - current liabilities = working capitalAs with cash burn rate, both high and low working capital can be a cause for concern. Negative working capital indicates that a company is in financial difficulty, but a high working capital could mean a company isnâ€™t making the most of its available assets or investing in long-term growth.Â [Related: Net working capital: How to calculate it and why it's important]Customer Acquisition Cost (CAC)Customer acquisition cost (CAC) is a measurement of how much money it takes for your business to win a new customer. CAC is an important metric in business performance management, as it indicates whether your sales and marketing strategy is working efficiently.The formula for calculating CAC is:

Cost of sales and marketing / number of new customers acquired = CACWhen calculating CAC, you should include sales and marketing spend, salaries, bonuses and overheads.Â Â Â CAC is an important metric for any business that uses sales and marketing to generate new customers. That includes eCommerce businesses, professional services, and even bricks and mortar businesses such as supermarkets.Â Ultimately, the less you spend on acquiring new customers, the greater your profit margins will be.Â When looking at CAC, itâ€™s important to think about the lifetime value (or CLV) of the customers you acquire. This is an obvious consideration for SaaS businesses and other enterprises that collect recurring revenue from their customers, but CLV can also be applied to other businesses.Â For example, an eCommerce business has a CAC of Â£50, and the average order value on their website is Â£55. This low margin initially causes concern, but after analysing the data, the business finds that a large percentage of its customer base return to make further purchases.Â Using this data, the business finds that the average customer lifetime value is Â£800, thereby justifying their CAC.Â Â Â 
Customer lifetime valueCustomer lifetime value (CLV) is a performance metric that measures the revenue your customers bring in throughout their relationship with your business.It costs more money to acquire new customers than it does to keep existing ones, so increasing CLV is an obvious lever to pull to maximise the profitability of your business.Â CLV also offers a good insight into your customer satisfaction. If your customers continue to use your products over an extended period of time, it means youâ€™re doing something right.You can use CLV to determine whether your customer acquisition cost (CAC) is justified, and when deciding your pricing strategy. The formula for calculating customer lifetime value is:Annual customer value x average customer lifespan in years =Â  CLVIn order to measure CLV, you need to understand your customer lifecycle. If you own an eCommerce business, that means tracking the purchase frequency of your returning customers. If you own a subscription business, it means understanding your upsells, cross sells and churn rate.Â [Related: Stop overlooking customer lifetime value in eCommerce]Payback periodsAs a founder, it can be difficult to decide which initiatives to invest in. Should you put your budget into developing a new product? Or should you spend money on equipment that will help your team work more efficiently?Â Â Payback periods allow you to calculate the opportunity and risk associated with an investment. The shorter the payback period, the better the investment.Â The formula for calculating payback period is:Investment / annual cashflow from investment = payback periodÂ Payback period is a useful metric to use when building a business plan, as it helps you prioritise where to spend your budget.Â [Related: Determining payback periods: How to plan for startup success]Gross, operating and net profit marginProfit margin shows the revenue your company has retained after expenses have been accounted for, and offers a clear indication of the growth potential of your business.Â Â Â There are three ways to calculate profit margin, and all of them are usually expressed as a percentage.Â Gross profit marginGross profit margin shows the percentage of revenue that remains after accounting for cost of goods sold (COGS).The formula for calculating gross profit margin is:(Gross profit / revenue) x 100 = gross profit marginOperating profit marginOperating profit margin shows the percentage of revenue that remains after accounting for operating, administrative, sales and overhead costs. The formula for calculating operating profit margin is:(Operating income / revenue) x 100 = operating profit margin
Net profit marginNet profit margin is your bottom line. This is the amount of revenue you have left after accounting for all expenses, including operating costs, overheads, COGS, tax, one off expenses and debt repayments.Â The formula for calculating net profit margin is:(Net income / revenue) x 100 = net profit marginProfitability metrics vary by industry, so itâ€™s best to benchmark your business against others in your sector. You can also use profitability metrics to understand how your business is performing YOY.Â ğŸŒÂ Top tip: Airwallex helps startup founders scale their business globally whilst improving profit margins. Our bank-beating FX rates and foreign currency accounts can help you add 4% back into your bottom line. To learn more, sign up free today.Â  
Net revenue retentionÂ Net revenue retention (NRR) is a key performance metric for SaaS businesses and other companies that operate under a recurring revenue model. It shows the percentage of revenue retained from existing customers over a period of time.Â NRR takes into account your monthly recurring revenue, the additional revenue you have generated from upselling and cross selling to your existing customers, and the revenue you have lost from customers that have churned or downgraded their subscription plan.Â Â NRR is a great way to measure customer success and establish the profitability of your pricing models.Â Â The formula for calculating NRR is:[(total revenue + expansion revenue) â€“ churn] / total revenue = NRR[Related: Net revenue retention and the 3 things every venture capitalist looks for]Monthly recurring revenue (MRR)Monthly recurring revenue (MRR) is another key performance metric for SaaS businesses, streaming services, and other companies that follow a recurring revenue model.Â MRR provides a simple and effective way to measure your businessâ€™ growth, and predict future cash flow.Â If your MRR isnâ€™t moving in the right direction, you may have an issue with customer churn, in which case you should look into ways to improve customer satisfaction and product market fit.Â In order to calculate MRR, you first need to know your average revenue per user (ARPU). Once you have this, the formula is simple:Monthly ARPU x number of monthly users = MRRChurn rateChurn rate is the main metric which SaaS companies and other businesses that follow a monthly recurring revenue model use to measure customer success.Â Simply put, churn measures the number of customers that stop using your product or service over a period of time. The lower your churn rate, the higher your customer retention, and the more monthly recurring revenue (MRR) you will make.Â Churn rate is expressed as a percentage, the formula is:(Customers at the beginning of the month - customers at the end of the month) / customers at the beginning of the month = churn rateAs a startup founder itâ€™s essential that you keep a close eye on your churn rate. All businesses experience some churn, but if your churn rate is creeping up MOM, you may need to assess the value that you are offering your customers versus competitors.Â Remember, it costs more to acquire new customers than it does to retain existing ones, so keeping churn rate low should always be a priority.Â Improve profit margins and scale your business with AirwallexÂ The key to running a successful business is to grow and retain your customers whilst keeping profit margins high.Â Â Hereâ€™s where Airwallex can give you an advantage over competitors.Â Airwallex helps thousands of startup founders streamline their finances and push into new markets whilst cutting out needless costs.Whether youâ€™re looking to expand your eCommerce business internationally, build a market-leading FX rate into your SaaS product, or simply cut the cost of international payments, Airwallex can help you do it.Â With an Airwallex account, you can collect customer revenue in multiple currencies without being subject to forced FX conversions or unnecessary fees, adding up to 4% back into your bottom line.Â You can also cut the cost of paying international suppliers with our bank-beating FX rates, and enjoy borderless spending with our virtual and physical Employee Cards.Â Airwallex is your complete financial suite for global money management. Sign up free today and take your business further.Â 
Back to blogShareTilly MichellContent Marketing ManagerTilly manages the content strategy for Airwallex. She specialises in content that supports businesses in their growth trajectory.
